bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, April 2, 1902
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No. 90. Consular, Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, April 2, 1902.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. The whereabouts of Alfred Whitted.
No. 90, Consular Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, April 2, 1902
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt March 28, 1902, of your No. 40, Consular, of February 19, 1902. relative to the "whereabouts of Mr. Alfred Whitted," by the Third Assistant Secretary of State, with enclosures. In reply, I am sory to have to convey to you the sad intelligence that Mr. Alfred Whitted, late of Danville Ill. more recently of Brewerville, Liberia, the brother of Mr. Horatio Whitted of the General Land

Land Office, Washington D. C>, resided at Royesville, Mantsurado County Liberia. He came to this city sometime in November 1901. He was sick when he came to the city. He died in this city, December 1, 1901, and was buried here, in the Monrovia Cemetery.

He was married. His widowed wife, without child, resided at Reyerville this County, and is known by the name of Mrs. Lydia Whitted. As there is no Post Office at Rayerville, all mail matter must be addressed to Monrovia.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
